chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management of tinnitus
chapter.summary: Provides advice on the management of tinnitus in primary care and when to refer people with tinnitus for secondary care assessment and management.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 16 years onwards.

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I refer someone with tinnitus to secondary care?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Refer people with tinnitus immediately (to be seen within a few hours, or more quickly if necessary) if it is associated with: 
    • A high risk of suicide — refer to a crisis mental health management team for assessment. 
      • If required, provide a safe place while waiting for assessment.
    • Sudden onset of significant neurological symptoms or signs (for example, facial weakness) — refer for neurological assessment. 
    • Acute uncontrolled vestibular symptoms (for example, vertigo) — refer for neurological assessment. 
    • Suspected stroke – follow a local stroke referral pathway.
  • Also refer people immediately with:
    • Sudden onset pulsatile tinnitus. 
    • Tinnitus secondary to head trauma. 
  • Refer people very urgently (to be seen within 24 hours) if they have tinnitus and hearing loss that has developed suddenly (over a period of 3 days or less) in the past 30 days – refer to ear, nose, and throat or an emergency department. 
  • Refer people urgently (to be seen within 2 weeks) if they have tinnitus associated with:
    • Distress affecting mental wellbeing (for example, distress that prevents them from carrying out their usual daily activities) even after receiving tinnitus support at first point of contact with a healthcare professional. 
    • Hearing loss that developed suddenly more than 30 days ago, or rapidly worsening hearing loss (over a period of 4–90 days) – refer to an ear, nose, and throat or audiovestibular service.
    • Persistent otalgia or otorrhoea that does not resolve with routine treatment. 
  • Refer people in line with local pathways if they have: 
    • Tinnitus that bothers them despite having received tinnitus support at first point of contact with a healthcare professional.
    • Persistent objective tinnitus.
    • Tinnitus associated with unilateral or asymmetric hearing loss.
  • Consider referring people for tinnitus assessment and management in line with local pathways if they have: 
    • Persistent pulsatile tinnitus.
      • Offer imaging to all people with pulsatile tinnitus.
    • Persistent unilateral tinnitus. 
  • Refer less urgently to an ear, nose, and throat specialist (using clinical judgement): 
    • Tinnitus of uncertain cause. This includes people with tinnitus that is not associated with hearing loss, ear pain, drainage or malodour, vestibular symptoms or facial weakness, and people with hearing loss that cannot clearly be distinguished as either sensorineural or conductive.
  • Offer an audiological assessment for all people with tinnitus, particularly if it is persistent (lasting 6 months or more).

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are largely based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidelines Tinnitus: assessment and management [NICE, 2020a], Hearing loss in adults: assessment and management [NICE, 2018], Suspected neurological conditions: recognition and referral [NICE, 2019], the British Medical Journal (BMJ) best practice guide Tinnitus [BMJ Best Practice, 2017], the British Tinnitus Association Tinnitus guidance for GPs [British Tinnitus Association, 2017], the American Academy of Otolaryngology - Head and Neck Surgery Foundation Clinical practice guideline: tinnitus [Tunkel, 2014], and expert opinion in a review article A triage guide for tinnitus [Henry et al, 2010].

Refer immediately or urgently
  • Expert opinion in a review article [Henry et al, 2010] suggests that tinnitus and symptoms, such as facial paralysis, severe vertigo, or sudden onset pulsatile tinnitus, that could indicate a serious underlying condition should be treated as an otologic emergency as they may indicate cerebrovascular disease or neoplasm. This is supported by recommendations from the British Tinnitus Association [British Tinnitus Association, 2017] and expert opinion in other review articles [Baguley, 2013; BMJ Best Practice, 2017].
    • A guideline from the American Academy of Otolaryngology - Head and Neck Surgery Foundation suggests that vertigo or balance problems in association with tinnitus can be caused by cochlear, retrocochlear, or other central nervous system disorders (including Meniere's disease and acoustic neuroma) and that vestibular assessment and imaging may be required [Tunkel, 2014].
  • Sudden hearing loss in association with tinnitus needs prompt treatment to stabilize or improve the person's hearing [Tunkel, 2014].
  • Expert opinion in review articles suggest that pulsatility is a red flag for tinnitus and recommends that, regardless of audiology results, people with pulsatile tinnitus should receive imaging to rule out skull base tumours and vascular lesions, such as arteriovenous malformation and fistulas [Meehan and Nogueira, 2014; Zimmerman, 2014; BMJ Best Practice, 2017]. Investigations for pulsatile tinnitus may include ultrasound scanning, CT, MRI, and angiography (sometimes in conjunction with CT or MRI imaging) [Baguley, 2013; Zimmerman, 2014]. 
Unilateral tinnitus
  • NICE advises that clinicians should consider referring people with persistent unilateral tinnitus in line with local pathways [NICE, 2020a]. 
  • Unilateral tinnitus is much less common than bilateral tinnitus and may indicate a more serious underlying condition such as acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma), cerebellopontine angle tumour, glomus tumour, or Meniere's disease. An MRI scan is likely to be requested [Henry et al, 2010; Tunkel, 2014; BMJ Best Practice, 2017].
Tinnitus associated with unilateral or asymmetric hearing loss
  • NICE advises that people with unilateral or asymmetric hearing loss should be referred in line with local pathways [NICE, 2020a]. 
  • A guideline from the American Academy of Otolaryngology - Head and Neck Surgery Foundation notes that unilateral or asymmetric hearing loss can be related to serious diagnoses such as acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma) [Tunkel, 2014]. Expert opinion in review articles states that people for whom tinnitus or hearing loss is asymmetric need referral for further investigations, such as MRI scanning [Baguley, 2013; Meehan and Nogueira, 2014; Zimmerman, 2014]. 
Tinnitus associated with persistent otalgia or otorrhoea that does not resolve with routine treatment
  • Otorrhoea can indicate middle ear infection or otitis externa [Tunkel, 2014] and in rare cases, cholesteatoma [Chang, 2008]. Expert opinion in a review article recommends urgent referral to an ear, nose, and throat specialist for an examination as soon as possible [Henry et al, 2010]. 
Refer less urgently (using clinical judgement)
  • Expert opinion in a review article acknowledges that people with no serious symptoms can be seen non-urgently [Henry et al, 2010]. 
  • The recommendations to refer people with tinnitus of uncertain cause is pragmatic and based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice taking into account expert opinion that people with symptoms suggestive of a sensorineural tinnitus without ear pain, drainage or malodour, vestibular symptoms, sudden hearing loss, or facial weakness/paralysis should be seen non-urgently by an ear, nose, and throat specialist [Henry et al, 2010].
  • Referring people with tinnitus causing distress despite primary care management reflects expert opinion from the British Tinnitus Association [British Tinnitus Association, 2017], and expert opinion in a review article [BMJ Best Practice, 2017].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage someone with tinnitus in primary care?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If indicated, refer the person for specialist assessment and management.
  • If referral is not required:
    • Reassure the person that: 
      • Tinnitus is a common condition.
      • It may resolve by itself.
      • Although it is commonly associated with hearing loss, it is not commonly associated with underlying physical problems.
      • There are a variety of management strategies that help many people live well with tinnitus.
    • Treat the underlying cause of tinnitus when possible, for example impacted wax, otitis media/externa, or temporomandibular joint dysfunction. For more information, see the CKS topics on Earwax, Otitis externa, Otitis media - acute, and Temporomandibular disorders (TMDs).
    • Review medications and, if appropriate, consider stopping a drug that may be causing tinnitus.
    • Discuss using sound therapy to reduce the impact of tinnitus. Advise the person to try having continuous, low-level, unobtrusive sound in the background to distract from the tinnitus (for example quiet music, noise from a water feature, the sound of a fan).
      • Further information about sound therapy is available from the British Tinnitus Association at www.tinnitus.org.uk, including a self-help information sheet on Sound therapy (sound enrichment). 
    • Consider a stepped approach to psychological therapies for people with tinnitus-related distress — if the person does not benefit from the first psychological intervention or declines an intervention, offer the next step in the following order:
      • Digital tinnitus-related cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) provided by psychologists.
      • Group-based tinnitus-related psychological interventions, including mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (delivered by appropriately trained and supervised practitioners), acceptance and commitment therapy or CBT (delivered by psychologists).
      • Individual tinnitus-related CBT (delivered by psychologists).
    • Offer a hearing aid to people with tinnitus who have hearing loss that affects their ability to communicate — refer the person to an audiologist.
      • Consider offering a hearing aid to people with tinnitus who have hearing loss but no difficulties communicating.
      • Do not offer a hearing aid to people with tinnitus but no hearing loss. 
    • Address any associated depression, anxiety, or insomnia. This may involve referral to a mental health professional. For more information, see the CKS topics on Depression, Generalized anxiety disorder, and Insomnia.
    • Medication and complementary and alternative therapies (such as dietary supplements, herbal medicines, acupuncture) are generally not recommended for the treatment of tinnitus.
    • Provide information and self-care advice about tinnitus: 
      • What it is.
      • What can make tinnitus worse (for example, stress or exposure to loud noise).
      • Safe listening practices (for example, noise protection).
      • The impact of tinnitus (for example, it can affect sleep).
      • Investigations that may be required in secondary care.
      • Self-help and coping strategies (for example, self-help books and relaxation strategies).
      • Management options.
    • Also provide information about local and national charities and support groups, including:
      • Action on hearing loss (www.actionnonhearingloss.org.uk) — Understanding tinnitus.
      • British Tinnitus Association (www.tinnitus.org.uk) — produces an extensive range of tinnitus-related information leaflets including All about tinnitus, Pulsatile tinnitus, and Self help for tinnitus. The telephone helpline number is 0800 018 0527.
      • ENT UK (www.entuk.org) — About tinnitus.
      • NHS A to Z (www.nhs.uk) — Tinnitus.
    • Arrange follow up to assess the person's response to treatment. Refer people who cannot be adequately managed in primary care.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are largely based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Tinnitus: assessment and management [NICE, 2020a], the British Medical Journal (BMJ) best practice guide Tinnitus [BMJ Best Practice, 2017], and the British Tinnitus Association Tinnitus guidance for GPs [British Tinnitus Association, 2017]. 

Treating the underlying cause
  • The recommendation to treat an underlying cause of tinnitus is based on US tinnitus guidelines [Tunkel, 2014; Yew, 2014] and expert opinion in review articles [Ruppert, 2012; BMJ Best Practice, 2017]. Managing the cause of tinnitus can improve symptoms or stop them progressing [Ruppert, 2012] and may remove the need for further treatment [BMJ Best Practice, 2017].
  • Reviewing medication and considering stopping ototoxic drugs is recommended by experts in review articles [Henry et al, 2010; Ruppert, 2012; Zimmerman, 2014].
Discussing the use of sound therapy
  • NICE was unable to make a recommendation on the use of sound therapy as there is limited evidence to assess the clinical and cost-effectiveness of these interventions in isolation, and insufficient evidence for any particular type of sound therapy [NICE, 2020a]. 
    • However, i​​​​​n the evidence review for sound therapy and amplification devices the committee noted that sound therapy and sound enrichment devices are widely used in the NHS and highlighted that from their clinical experience people with tinnitus do benefit from the use of these interventions [NICE, 2020c].  
  • A clinical practice guideline from the American Academy of Otolaryngology - Head and Neck Surgery Foundation on Tinnitus recommends sound therapy for people with persistent bothersome tinnitus based on randomized controlled trial evidence (RCT) [Tunkel, 2014]. This approach is supported by other experts [Ruppert, 2012; Baguley, 2013; Meehan and Nogueira, 2014] and the specific advice offered by CKS is based on that suggested by the British Tinnitus Association [British Tinnitus Association, 2017]. 
  • Potential benefits of sound therapy include helping habituation to tinnitus by decreasing the contrast between tinnitus and environmental sounds, administering soothing sounds to aid relaxation and stress-relief, and offering a distraction from tinnitus [Tunkel, 2014]. Sounds can be provided through hearing aids, portable devices, conventional stereophonic equipment, and pillow speakers [Hobson et al, 2012; Meehan and Nogueira, 2014]. 
  • A Cochrane systematic review: Sound therapy (masking) in the management of tinnitus in adults (search date February 2012) included six trials with 553 participants. No significant change in the loudness or severity of tinnitus was found after using sound therapy compared with management strategies, such as environmental sound exposure, counselling, tinnitus retraining, and patient education and relaxation. However, the Cochrane authors noted the significant heterogeneity between studies and concluded that although there was no strong evidence to support the efficacy of sound therapy, bearing in mind the methodological limitations of the evidence, this should not be interpreted as evidence that sound therapy is not effective [Hobson et al, 2012].
Considering tinnitus counselling or cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT)
  • NICE recommends psychological therapies for people whose tinnitus is still causing an impact on their emotional and social wellbeing and day-to-day activities despite having received tinnitus support [NICE, 2020a].  
  • Expert opinion in a German guideline [AWMF, 2015], US guidelines [Tunkel, 2014; Yew, 2014], and review articles [Henry et al, 2010; Ruppert, 2012] also supports this. 
    • CBT has been found to be effective in improving tinnitus distress, quality of life, and depression scores [AWMF, 2015]. RCT evidence suggests a favourable benefit:harm ratio [Tunkel, 2014].
  • The purpose of counselling is to support people with tinnitus in understanding the symptom and learning to live with it [Yew, 2014]. It is often recommended to treat chronic tinnitus, but in studies has only been compared with other interventions (for example tinnitus retraining and CBT) [Zenner, 2017]. 
  • CBT identifies and aims to change negative thought patterns and behaviours and use thinking strategies to reduce anxiety about tinnitus [Meehan and Nogueira, 2014]. A Cochrane systematic review (search date May 2010) on CBT for tinnitus found eight trials (n = 468) and concluded that although there was no evidence of a significant difference in the subjective loudness of the tinnitus with CBT compared with no treatment or another intervention in six of the studies, there was a significant improvement in depression score (in six studies) and quality of life (in five studies) [Martinez-Devesa et al, 2010]. A subsequent systematic review found a reduction in distress associated with tinnitus after CBT but advised caution given the small number of large well-controlled trials [Hesser, 2011].
  • A form of structured counselling combined with non-masking white noise or tinnitus-masking devices (tinnitus retraining therapy) to reduce the contrast between tinnitus and the surrounding environment may be available [Meehan and Nogueira, 2014; BMJ Best Practice, 2017]. The aim of the intervention is to address the sensations, emotions, and behaviour associated with tinnitus, but systematic reviews found insufficient evidence on which to draw firm conclusions on its effectiveness [Phillips and McFerran, 2010; Grewal, 2014].
Offering a hearing aid to people with tinnitus and hearing loss
  • NICE recommends offering amplification devices to people with hearing loss that affects their ability to communicate, and considering offering them to people with tinnitus who have hearing loss but no difficulties in communicating [NICE, 2020a]. 
    • NICE found limited evidence on using amplification devices for managing tinnitus. The committee noted that many people present with tinnitus without realising that they have hearing loss, and agreed that adults with tinnitus and hearing loss that affects their ability to communicate and hear should be offered an amplification device in line with the NICE guideline on hearing loss in adults. 
    • There was no evidence to support the use of amplification devices for people with tinnitus and a hearing loss that does not cause difficulties communicating. However, given that enhancing auditory input may improve the person's perception of tinnitus, the committee recommended that amplification devices be considered.
    • People without hearing loss should not be offered amplification devices as amplified sound may induce hearing loss.
  • Although RCT evidence supporting the use of hearing aids in people with tinnitus and hearing loss is limited [Hoare et al, 2014], their provision in this situation is recommended by the British Tinnitus Association even for people with a relatively mild hearing loss [British Tinnitus Association, 2017]. Hearing aids are also widely advised by expert opinion in guidelines (based on observational studies) [Tunkel, 2014] and review articles [Henry et al, 2010; Ruppert, 2012; Meehan and Nogueira, 2014; Zimmerman, 2014].
  • It is thought that hearing aids reduce listening effort [British Tinnitus Association, 2017] and decrease the perception of tinnitus by increasing the volume of ambient sounds [Henry et al, 2010; Zimmerman, 2014]. Some hearing aids incorporate sound therapy devices specifically for people with tinnitus [British Tinnitus Association, 2017].
Addressing anxiety, depression, or insomnia
  • The recommendation to address associated depression, anxiety, or insomnia is based on advice from the British Tinnitus Association [British Tinnitus Association, 2017] and expert opinion in review articles [Henry et al, 2010; Ruppert, 2012; Zimmerman, 2014]. Anxiety, depression, and insomnia are not causes as such, but can exacerbate tinnitus or act as triggers [Zimmerman, 2014].
  • The involvement of mental health specialists and psychologists in the management of a person with clinically significant tinnitus helps to address psychological barriers to successful tinnitus treatment [Henry et al, 2010]. In the guideline Tinnitus guidance for GPs, the British Tinnitus Association recommends urgent mental health support if there is the possibility of self-harm or psychological crisis [British Tinnitus Association, 2017]. 
Treatments not recommended
  • Extensive opinion in the literature describes the doubtful efficacy of medication for the treatment of tinnitus and the lack of evidence to support its use [Ruppert, 2012; Meehan and Nogueira, 2014; Zimmerman, 2014; Tunkel, 2014; AWMF, 2015; British Tinnitus Association, 2017]. Evidence is also lacking for complementary and alternative therapies [Ruppert, 2012; Baguley, 2013; Tunkel, 2014; Zimmerman, 2014; Zenner, 2017] so CKS was unable to make a recommendation on their use.
Follow up
  • This recommendation is pragmatic and is based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
